div.p: From Joseph Hooker to Henry Barkly
RBG Kew, archives, Letters from Joseph Hooker vol. 1, Ada-Bar, ff. 202-3.

This volume consists mainly of transcriptions, most in the form of typescript carbon copies, of Hooker's letters. There is no indication in the volume as to the date or author of the transcriptions, or the location of the originals, and the Archivist at Kew in June 2000 had no knowledge of the provenance of the volume. Folios 152-260 are to Sir Henry Barkly, October 1865 to November 1876, with one of 18 August 1866 (possibly an enclosure) to Charles Meller (see below) and ff. 261-3 to Lady Annie M. Barkly, July-August 1867. There are some gaps in the text and a few possible misreadings. Many letters have been annotated or asterisked in red ink or in pencil. Each letter in the Barkly series has been numbered. The subjects of the early letters are Hooker's various difficulties with the Board of Works 'under a department of Govt. already tired of scientific expenditure on Kew' (19 January 1866; f. 154), and Meller's journey to and health, conduct, and position at Mauritius, where Barkly was Governor, which apparently gave cause for concern. No. 14a

[…]
Text not related to M is omitted here and below.

I am distressed about poor Mueller, who has lost heart; and I hear friends too, by his uncontrollable self-esteem &c; the Government has cut his establishment down ad absurdam, and he does not bear his reverses with equanimity. I wish I could have induced him to steal a march on his enemies and ask boldly for a good Landscape Gardener and cultivator, to be employed under himself; but the poor fellow cannot brook an inferior or even subordinate with special knowledge which he does not possess, and I am very sure that he can no more manage that Garden without a practical Horticulturist, than I can this. The poor soul floods me with letters craving for sympathy,
See, for example, M to J. Hooker, 4 November 1872. and I heartily pity — but he wont take advice, and provokes his best Colonial friends.

The discovery of groves of Cycas in the Fitzalan Range,
Fitzalan Range not found in gazetteers. In his letters announcing the sending of the Cycas stems (see below), M does not use this geographic name. It may be an interpretation of Hooker's manuscript made by whoever provided the typescript. 20-40 ft high, is a most remarkable one; Mueller has sent me one of 12 feet, but as yet it shows no signs of growth.
M sent Hooker Cycas stems from Qld; see M to J. Hooker, 7 August 1872, and J. Hooker to M, 20 November 1872. A stem sprouted in 1875; see J. Hooker to M, 10 March 1875 (in this edition as 75-03-10a).

Bentham is at Orchideae for Flora Australica.
sic, i.e. Bentham (1863-78). I really hope that he will live to accomplish completion of that work! he is 71, but very hale, and continues to spend 5 days of the 7 at Kew, on it and the Gen. Plant.
Bentham & Hooker (1862-83).
